articles.headline: U.S. to Offer Oil Leases in the Gulf
articles.snippet: A proposed sale, scheduled for Dec. 14, will be the first in the part of the gulf bordering Texas since the summer of 2009 and the first sale of any kind in the gulf since March 2010.
articles.abstract: A proposed sale, scheduled for Dec. 14, will be the first in the part of the gulf bordering Texas since the summer of 2009 and the first sale of any kind in the gulf since March 2010.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Making good on a promise, the Interior Department announced Friday that it had scheduled its first sale of offshore oil leases in the Gulf of Mexico since the Deepwater Horizon disaster last year. But it is changing some of the rules to ensure that leased parcels are actually drilled and not hoarded.

articles.headline: A Long Peace Is Threatened in Israel Attack
articles.snippet: An Israeli strike aimed at militants killed three Egyptian officers, raising tensions the day after attacks near the border that killed eight Israelis.
articles.abstract: An Israeli strike aimed at militants killed three Egyptian officers, raising tensions the day after attacks near the border that killed eight Israelis.
articles.lead_paragraph: CAIRO — A cross-border terrorist attack and an Israeli retaliation that left three Egyptian officers dead are threatening to undermine a decades-old cold peace between the two countries that had already begun to fray since the revolution that ousted President Hosni Mubarak of Egypt.
articles.byline: By Heba Afify and Isabel Kershner

articles.headline: Questioning the Dogma of Tax Rates
articles.snippet: The idea of equalizing capital gains and ordinary income rates has become the third rail of tax policy and electoral politics.
articles.abstract: The idea of equalizing capital gains and ordinary income rates has become the third rail of tax policy and electoral politics.
articles.lead_paragraph: Warren Buffett pays a lower tax rate than his secretary and the 19 other people who work in his office. He pays a much lower rate than I do, and, I suspect, lower than nearly everyone reading this column. So, no doubt, do a long list of American billionaires, including Stephen Schwarzman of Blackstone and the hedge fund king John Paulson.

articles.headline: In a Race to Out-Rave, 5-Star Web Reviews Go for $5
articles.snippet: A thriving industry is buying and selling rapturous reviews on the Web, and academics and businesses are looking for ways to ferret out the fakes.
articles.abstract: A thriving industry is buying and selling rapturous reviews on the Web, and academics and businesses are looking for ways to ferret out the fakes.
articles.lead_paragraph: In tens of millions of reviews on Web sites like Amazon.com, Citysearch, TripAdvisor and Yelp, new books are better than Tolstoy, restaurants are undiscovered gems and hotels surpass the Ritz.

articles.headline: Antibacterial Chemical Raises Safety Issues
articles.snippet: Regulators, consumer advocates and soap manufacturers are locked in a battle over triclosan, the active ingredient in antibacterial soaps like Dial Complete.
articles.abstract: Regulators, consumer advocates and soap manufacturers are locked in a battle over triclosan, the active ingredient in antibacterial soaps like Dial Complete.
articles.lead_paragraph: The maker of Dial Complete hand soap says that it kills more germs than any other brand. But is it safe?

articles.headline: As PCs Wane, Companies Look to Tablets
articles.snippet: Computer makers are expected to ship only about 4 percent more PCs this year than last year, while tablets are flying off store shelves.
articles.abstract: Computer makers are expected to ship only about 4 percent more PCs this year than last year, while tablets are flying off store shelves.
articles.lead_paragraph: Although the world is dependent on personal computers, making them has not been a great business for most American companies for almost a decade.
articles.byline: By Verne G. Kopytoff and Ian Austen

articles.headline: If Phones Ring, Obama Is Here, With Cell Power
articles.snippet: Spotty cellular service magically improves on Martha’s Vineyard when President Obama and his family arrive for what has become a yearly August vacation.
articles.abstract: Spotty cellular service magically improves on Martha’s Vineyard when President Obama and his family arrive for what has become a yearly August vacation.
articles.lead_paragraph: CHILMARK, Mass. — To the slamming screen door, happy vacation chatter and other noises at the Chilmark General Store, add a less expected one this month: ringing cellphones.

articles.headline: Qaddafi’s Hold in Tripoli in Doubt as Rebels Advance
articles.snippet: Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi’s hold on his Tripoli stronghold shows signs of slipping as residents said they believed his flight or ouster could be imminent.
articles.abstract: Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi’s hold on his Tripoli stronghold shows signs of slipping as residents said they believed his flight or ouster could be imminent.
articles.lead_paragraph: CAIRO — Six months after the outbreak of the revolt against his 42 years in power, Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi’s hold on his Tripoli stronghold shows signs of slipping.

articles.headline: Heavy Fighting Reported in Tripoli; Rebels Encircle City
articles.snippet: Rebel leaders in Tunis and eastern Libya characterized it as the beginning of a new uprising in the capital as Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi’s hold in Libya seemed to slip.
articles.abstract: Rebel leaders in Tunis and eastern Libya characterized it as the beginning of a new uprising in the capital as Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi’s hold in Libya seemed to slip.
articles.lead_paragraph: ZAWIYAH, Libya — For the first time in months, witnesses in Tripoli reported heavy fighting across the capital late Saturday night, even as rebel forces claimed to have encircled the city by taking major towns to its east, west and south.
articles.byline: By Kareem Fahim and David D. Kirkpatrick

articles.headline: In Silicon Valley, the Night Is Still Young
articles.snippet: Even as memories of the dot-com bust rustle in the background, Silicon Valley is still thriving and generally optimistic.
articles.abstract: Even as memories of the dot-com bust rustle in the background, Silicon Valley is still thriving and generally optimistic.
articles.lead_paragraph: MENLO PARK, Calif.

articles.headline: Finger-Pointing in the Fog
articles.snippet: The lawsuits have been flying after five Wisconsin school districts lost millions of dollars in complex debt securities.
articles.abstract: The lawsuits have been flying after five Wisconsin school districts lost millions of dollars in complex debt securities.
articles.lead_paragraph: UNEARTHING the story of the financial crisis is like conducting an archaeological dig. New shards keep emerging from the dust.

articles.headline: In Father’s Memory, Fighting to Stay in Britain
articles.snippet: Britain repels illegal immigrants through an enforcement system partly run by private contractors, but it has legitimized treating foreigners as scapegoats.
articles.abstract: Britain repels illegal immigrants through an enforcement system partly run by private contractors, but it has legitimized treating foreigners as scapegoats.
articles.lead_paragraph: CLAPHAM, England — The boy was 13 when a dawn immigration raid abruptly ended his father’s four-year quest for political asylum in Britain. By nightfall of that day in 2005, father and son were hundreds of miles from home, locked in the privately run Yarl’s Wood Immigration Removal Center here, scheduled for deportation to their native Angola in the morning.

articles.headline: Perry Mines Texas System to Raise Cash for Campaigns
articles.snippet: Over three terms in office, Gov. Rick Perry has doled out state aid to his most generous supporters and their businesses.
articles.abstract: Over three terms in office, Gov. Rick Perry has doled out state aid to his most generous supporters and their businesses.
articles.lead_paragraph: Two years ago, John McHale, an entrepreneur from Austin, Tex., who has given millions of dollars to Democratic candidates and causes, did something very unusual for him: he wrote a $50,000 check to a Republican candidate, Rick Perry, then seeking a third full term as governor of Texas. In September 2010, he did it again, catapulting himself into the top ranks of Mr. Perry’s donors.
articles.byline: By Nicholas Confessore and Michael Luo

articles.headline: A Hollywood Anachronism, Serving Stars but Never Gossip
articles.snippet: As maître d’hôtel at the Tower Bar, Dmitri Dmitrov, a 60-year-old Macedonian immigrant, wields a subtle and steely power.
articles.abstract: As maître d’hôtel at the Tower Bar, Dmitri Dmitrov, a 60-year-old Macedonian immigrant, wields a subtle and steely power.
articles.lead_paragraph: WEST HOLLYWOOD, Calif. — Jennifer Aniston is Table 24, a coveted perch with a view of the piano yet screened from prying eyes by a bank of Casablanca lilies. Anderson Cooper is Table 11, with its panoramic view across the dining room. Sean Penn is Table 20, except on those nights when a certain agent he’s at war with is in the house. A major studio executive who dines on successive nights with his daughter, wife and mistress is guided to cozy spots at Tables 21, 22 and 12.

articles.headline: Jubilant Rebels Control Much of Tripoli
articles.snippet: Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi’s grip on power dissolved with astonishing speed as rebels marched into the capital and arrested two of his sons, while residents raucously celebrated the prospective end of his four-decade-old rule.
articles.abstract: Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi’s grip on power dissolved with astonishing speed as rebels marched into the capital and arrested two of his sons, while residents raucously celebrated the prospective end of his four-decade-old rule.
articles.lead_paragraph: TRIPOLI, Libya — Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi’s grip on power dissolved with astonishing speed on Monday as rebels marched into the capital and arrested two of his sons, while residents raucously celebrated the prospective end of his four-decade-old rule.
articles.byline: By Kareem Fahim and David D. Kirkpatrick

articles.headline: A Conservative Beachhead in the Sunshine
articles.snippet: Far from Tea Party country, South Florida has become a magnet for conservative media personalities.
articles.abstract: Far from Tea Party country, South Florida has become a magnet for conservative media personalities.
articles.lead_paragraph: PALM BEACH, Fla. — The mid-’90s were rough on Democrats, especially here in this beachhead of fabulously wealthy political donors. Their money wasn’t enough to keep the Democratic Party in control of Congress. The famous Kennedy estate on North Ocean Boulevard, known as the “Winter White House” during the administration of John F. Kennedy, was sold to a New York banker who now holds Republican fund-raisers there.

articles.headline: Comic’s PAC Is More Than a Gag
articles.snippet: By creating a legal and functioning political action committee, Stephen Colbert is not just lampooning the process, he has become a part of it.
articles.abstract: By creating a legal and functioning political action committee, Stephen Colbert is not just lampooning the process, he has become a part of it.
articles.lead_paragraph: Let’s start with a spot political quiz. Which of the following are legitimate political action committees known as Super PACs, and which is fake?

articles.headline: On Wall St., a Big Split on Outlook
articles.snippet: Company analysts have barely budged on expectations for earnings, even as economists at the big brokerage firms have steadily ratcheted down forecasts for economic growth.
articles.abstract: Company analysts have barely budged on expectations for earnings, even as economists at the big brokerage firms have steadily ratcheted down forecasts for economic growth.
articles.lead_paragraph: Amid all the grim economic data and a chorus of warnings of a fresh recession, one group on Wall Street has remained remarkably optimistic despite the dangers that may lie ahead — the research analysts who track individual companies.
articles.byline: By Nelson D. Schwartz and Eric Dash

articles.headline: Attorney General of N.Y. Is Said to Face Pressure on Bank Foreclosure Deal
articles.snippet: Attorney General Eric T. Schneiderman of New York is under pressure from the Obama administration to drop opposition to a state settlement with banks over foreclosure practices.
articles.abstract: Attorney General Eric T. Schneiderman of New York is under pressure from the Obama administration to drop opposition to a state settlement with banks over foreclosure practices.
articles.lead_paragraph: Eric T. Schneiderman, the attorney general of New York, has come under increasing pressure from the Obama administration to drop his opposition to a wide-ranging state settlement with banks over dubious foreclosure practices, according to people briefed on discussions about the deal.

articles.headline: Motorola’s Identity Crisis
articles.snippet: It is no secret that Google wanted Motorola’s patents; the challenge comes in defining what else Motorola can bring to the deal.
articles.abstract: It is no secret that Google wanted Motorola’s patents; the challenge comes in defining what else Motorola can bring to the deal.
articles.lead_paragraph: Hundreds of framed patents hang on two separate walls at the headquarters of Motorola Mobility in Libertyville, Ill. They testify to the pride in innovation at Motorola, a luminary of American business that has survived corporate crises and enormous technological change.
articles.byline: By Matt Richtel and Jenna Wortham

articles.headline: Local TV Newscasts Expanding
articles.snippet: Bolstered by revenue increases and improvements in news gathering, local television news is expanding in major markets.
articles.abstract: Bolstered by revenue increases and improvements in news gathering, local television news is expanding in major markets.
articles.lead_paragraph: ST. LOUIS — Coming soon to this city’s television screens: more news at 4 in the morning, again at 10, and at 4 in the afternoon.

articles.headline: Preaching a Healthy Diet in the Deep-Fried Delta
articles.snippet: In the Mississippi Delta, the Rev. Michael O. Minor is waging war against obesity and bad health, and the National Baptist Convention has taken up his campaign.
articles.abstract: In the Mississippi Delta, the Rev. Michael O. Minor is waging war against obesity and bad health, and the National Baptist Convention has taken up his campaign.
articles.lead_paragraph: HERNANDO, Miss. — Not much seems out of place in the Mississippi Delta, where everything appears to be as it always has been, only more so as the years go by. But here in the fellowship hall of a little Baptist church on a country road is an astonishing sight: a plate of fresh fruit.

articles.headline: Instead of a Bloody Struggle, a Headlong Rush Into a Cheering Capital
articles.snippet: The rebels’ advance into the heart of Tripoli was more of a Sunday drive than a final offensive.
articles.abstract: The rebels’ advance into the heart of Tripoli was more of a Sunday drive than a final offensive.
articles.lead_paragraph: TRIPOLI, Libya — In the end, it was more of a Sunday drive than a punishing final offensive.

articles.headline: Qaddafi’s Son Taunts Rebels in Tripoli
articles.snippet: Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi remained at large as his son Seif al-Islam made a surprise appearance at a hotel, and the jubilation that accompanied rebels’ advance Sunday yielded to a sense of a power vacuum.
articles.abstract: Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi remained at large as his son Seif al-Islam made a surprise appearance at a hotel, and the jubilation that accompanied rebels’ advance Sunday yielded to a sense of a power vacuum.
articles.lead_paragraph: TRIPOLI, Libya — The euphoria that followed the rebels’ triumphant march in Tripoli gave way to confusion and wariness on Monday, as Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi remained at large, his son Seif al-Islam made a surprise appearance at a hotel with foreign journalists, and pockets of loyalist forces stubbornly resisted rebel efforts to take control of the capital.
articles.byline: By David D. Kirkpatrick and Kareem Fahim
